## Assume breach, design for blast radius
- mTLS on every hop
- Per-service identity via SPIFFE
- Deny-by-default egress via a proxy
What happens when the noisiest service gets popped and the network is flat? Without uniform guardrails, lateral movement is trivial.

turns.speaker: application_engineer
turns.mdx:
## We need velocity
Full mesh + heavy policy on day one will kneecap devs. Latency, sidecars, cert churn.
- JWT at the edge via gateway
- mTLS only for critical paths first
- Audit policies before enforce
Do we really need uniform everywhere before we ship anything?

turns.speaker: security_engineer
turns.mdx:
## Weakest link, biggest blast
Your plan leaves soft targets attackers pivot through. Partial zero trust is zero trust in name only.
- Uniform mTLS cuts lateral paths
- Consider eBPF node agents if sidecars hurt
Assume compromise; minimize blast radius uniformly.

turns.speaker: application_engineer
turns.mdx:
## Scope and stage, not stall
I can accept uniform identity (SPIFFE), but keep authz coarse (RBAC) first. Canary enforcement, dev permissive, prod strict.
```yaml
allow: serviceA->serviceB if scope: orders
```
Let’s harden iteratively while we keep features moving.

## Non‑negotiables, with guardrails
- Workload identity + mTLS by default
- Deny‑by‑default east‑west
- Egress allowlist with logged break‑glass
```mermaid
flowchart LR
Client-->Gateway
Gateway-->A
A-->Policy
Policy-->B
```
Put a policy engine on every hop; no silent bypass.
